reference.shortdesc: The div element is used to organize subsets of content into logical groups that are not intended to be or should not be contained as a topic.

section.p: The div element is designed to be a grouping element; it does not imply any explicit semantics or contain an explicit title. This avoids enabling the creation of deeply-nested content that would otherwise be written as separate topics. If the content requires a title, use a section element, a nested topic, or possibly a fig element.

fig.title: Using div for grouping
fig.p: In the following example, a div element is used to organize several elements together so that they can be referenced by conref or conkeyref:
fig.codeblock:
...

The first paragraph

The second paragraph

This is a note
...
fig.p: Without using a div element, the content could not be grouped for content referencing since the start and end elements are of different types.

fig.title: Using div for specialization
fig.p: In the following example, div is used as the basis for specializing a new domain element, pullquote:
fig.codeblock:
<!ENTITY % pullquote.content "(%div.cnt;)*" > <!ENTITY % pullquote.attributes "%univ-atts; outputclass CDATA #IMPLIED" > <!ELEMENT pullquote %pullquote.content;> <!ATTLIST pullquote %pullquote.attributes;>
<!ATTLIST pullquote %global-atts; class CDATA "+ topic/div pubcontent-d/pullquote ">
fig.p: Instances of pullquote could then be used in both body and section contexts:
fig.codeblock:
My Article

Something pithy someone said

Something Pithy

This is really really pithy

Really Pithy
